docs.lead_paragraph: With the midterm elections five days away, Republicans are tempering expectations that they can expand their majority to 60 seats in the Senate. Some experts say that Republicans could still harvest a net gain of up to four Senate seats but that the party will fall shy of five. Five is the magic number that would vault Republicans to 60 seats and into the rarefied realm of a filibuster-proof majority in which they could cut off debate by the Democrats and control the legislative agenda.

headline.main: G.O.P.'s Hopes Dim for Filibuster-Proof Senate Margin

docs.abstract: Republicans temper expectations that they can expand their majority to 60 seats in Senate, which would give them filibuster-proof majority; photo (M)
docs.snippet: With the midterm elections five days away, Republicans are tempering expectations that they can expand their majority to 60 seats in the Senate.    Some experts say that Republicans could still harvest a net gain of up to four Senate seats but that...

docs.lead_paragraph: With a stern declaration that the law must protect all lives, a New Jersey judge today imposed a 15-year prison sentence on the young woman who had admitted killing her newborn son at her senior prom in 1997. The judge, John A. Ricciardi, said that the woman, Melissa Drexler, 20, would be eligible for her first parole hearing after serving 2 years and 11 months. Nevertheless, her 15-year sentence is far harsher than the 30-month and 24-month sentences that Amy Grossberg and Brian Peterson received, respectively. The teen-agers, both from Wycoff, admitted guilt in July in the death of their newborn son at a motel in Newark, Del., in November 1996.

headline.main: Woman Gets 15 Years in Death of Newborn at Prom

docs.abstract: New Jersey Judge John A Ricciardi imposes 15-year prison sentence on Melissa Drexler, young woman who has admitted killing her newborn son at her senior prom last year; photo (M)
